result.title: Bitmasks
result.content:
Bitmasks is how to do operations on the binary representation of the number, to do these operations we have some bitwise operators :

1 — or ( | )

it takes the binary representation of two numbers and then for every 2 adjacent bits if at least one of them is equal to 1 then there will be 1 in the result number in this bit

example

5 | 3 = 7

0101
0011
----
0111

2 — and ( & )

it takes the binary representation of two numbers and then for every 2 adjacent bits if at least one of them is equal to 0 then there will be 0 in the result number in this bit

example

5 & 3 = 1

0101
0011
----
0001

3 — exclusive or (xor) ( ^ )

it takes the binary representation of two numbers and then for every 2 adjacent bits if the 2 bits are similar then their will be zero in the result bit other wise it will be one.

example

5 ^ 3 = 6

0101
0011
----
0110

4 — not ( ~ )

it takes the binary representation of a number then it changes all zero bits into ones and all one bits into zero.

example

the integer has 32 bits so all of them will be changed but here i will show you only on 4 bits

~5 = 10 

0101
----
1010

5 — right shift ( >> )

it takes the binary representation of a number then it shifts it a specific number of bits to the right and puts zeros in the end.

example


5 >> 1 = 2
 
0101
----
0010

6 — left shift ( << )

it takes the binary representation of a number then it shifts it a specific number of bits to the left and puts zeros in the beginning.

example


5 << 1 = 10
 
0101
----
1010

some things you can do with these operators :

1- how to check if the 3rd bit is one : 

if (((number >> 2) & 1) == 1){}

2- get the number 2 ^ 5 (32) :

number = (1 << 5);

3- make a number that has all the bits ones except the 5th one :

number = ((~0) ^ (1 << 4));

and there are also many helpful things.
